usefulItems: ceramic ramekins (approx. Ø 8 cm, height 4.5 cm), baking paper
title: Chawan Mushi (Japanese Savoury Egg Custard)

ingredients.content: ½ tsp instant dashi powder (see variation)
100 g pork mince, broken in pieces (optional)
30 g fresh shiitake mushrooms, sliced, or any small mushrooms, sliced

preparations.content: Place eggs, 300 g water, salt, instant dashi powder, soy sauce, black pepper and pork mince (if using) in mixing bowl and mix <b>20 sec/speed 2.5<b>. Transfer to 6 ceramic ramekins (approx. Ø 8 cm, height 4.5 cm), filling to 1 cm from the top of each. Rinse mixing bowl.

Place remaining 500 g water in mixing bowl. Place 3 filled ramekins in Varoma dish and cover loosely with a sheet of baking paper. Insert Varoma tray, place remaining ramekins on it and cover again with a sheet of baking paper. Set Varoma in position and steam <b>12 min/Varoma/speed 1<b>.

Carefully remove Varoma lid and tray, lift sheets of baking paper and carefully arrange shiitake mushrooms, 1 prawn and 5 green peas on top of each steamed egg dish. Replace baking paper, set Varoma tray and lid back in position and steam a further <b>10 min/Varoma/speed 1<b>. Serve hot.

hintsAndTricks: This delicate steamed egg dish is served both at home and in restaurants in Japan. Adapt the toppings as you wish, choosing ingredients that will add both colour and flavour to the silky egg custard. Serve as a starter or as one of several small dishes as a main course. It can also be served chilled.

Dashi, or Japanese cooking stock, adds flavour to chawan mushi. You can replace instant dashi powder with <b>½ tsp homemade<b> chicken or vegetable stock paste: first dilute the stock paste in water before adding it in <b>step 1,<b> and reduce salt to <b>¼ tsp.<b> Or omit instant dashi powder and use <b>300 g stock<b> instead of water in <b>step 1.<b> Finally you can omit the instant dashi powder altogether; the dish will have a more subtle egg flavour that is also very pleasant.

Steam in any heat-resistant cups or small bowls of similar size. If your dishes are a different size or they are not ceramic, you may have to adjust the cooking time. Once you know the perfect cooking time for your own dishes, make a note for next time.
